comment:
Played in the "spirit of the hedgehog"
according to my book "Sizilianisch im Geiste des Igels".   played in the
"spirit of the hedgehog" according to my book

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. g3 b6 4. Bg2 Bb7 5. Nc3 d6 6. d4 cxd4 7. Nxd4 a6 8. O-O Nd7
comment:
This opening line is rarely seen. Perhaps
my move is already a novelty. This opening line is rarely seen. Perhaps my
move is already a novelty. You can reach the position from many different ways:
2. ...a6, 2. ...b6, 2. ...d6 and finally 2. ...e6, but in every occasion there
are plausible causes for both players to deviate. The black strategie, to slow
the development of the king's side while seizing a capable hedgehog-formation
on the other side, is a central thougt in my book.  In this special line it's
necessary not to engage the kings knight too early.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. g3 b6 4. Bg2 Bb7 5. Nc3 d6 6. d4 cxd4 7. Nxd4 a6 8. O-O Nd7 9. f4
comment:
the corresponding capter in my book
handles with two principle plans for white: first, to fight the cautious black
manouvers simply with pieces in the center - that means Re1, eventually Bg5
and culminates in the Nd5-sacrifice. In this case it's not so easy for white
to open files on the queenside, since black moved the b-pawn only to b6
instead of b5!   Second, to start a fierce pawn-attack on the kingside. In the
game white manages to combine this different strategic aims in a remarkable
way:

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. g3 b6 4. Bg2 Bb7 5. Nc3 d6 6. d4 cxd4 7. Nxd4 a6 8. O-O Nd7 9. f4 Ngf6
comment:
The treat was 10.f5 e6 11.
Ne6, but now black  neglects the "credo" of holding back the kings-knigt
development. The safer move is 9. ...Qc7, and 9. ...b6-b5 also deserves
attention. Now white has got a target...

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. g3 b6 4. Bg2 Bb7 5. Nc3 d6 6. d4 cxd4 7. Nxd4 a6 8. O-O Nd7 9. f4 Ngf6 10. Re1
1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. g3 b6 4. Bg2 Bb7 5. Nc3 d6 6. d4 cxd4 7. Nxd4 a6 8. O-O Nd7 9. f4 Ngf6 10. Re1 Qc7
comment:
I was not confident with this move, but I felt forced to do so. My
prefered move, the alternative ...h5!?, looks interesting, but the analyse
suggests a littlel but forced advantage for white:

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. g3 b6 4. Bg2 Bb7 5. Nc3 d6 6. d4 cxd4 7. Nxd4 a6 8. O-O Nd7 9. f4 Ngf6 10. Re1 Qc7 11. g4
comment: the immediate Nd5 looks overhasted. After

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. g3 b6 4. Bg2 Bb7 5. Nc3 d6 6. d4 cxd4 7. Nxd4 a6 8. O-O Nd7 9. f4 Ngf6 10. Re1 Qc7 11. g4 h6
comment:
ready to face the storm, but nevertheless very risky. The
"computer-move" 11. ...e5!? is not refutable. In any case black would get more
air to breath.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. g3 b6 4. Bg2 Bb7 5. Nc3 d6 6. d4 cxd4 7. Nxd4 a6 8. O-O Nd7 9. f4 Ngf6 10. Re1 Qc7 11. g4 h6 12. Nd5
1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. g3 b6 4. Bg2 Bb7 5. Nc3 d6 6. d4 cxd4 7. Nxd4 a6 8. O-O Nd7 9. f4 Ngf6 10. Re1 Qc7 11. g4 h6 12. Nd5 exd5 13. exd5+ Be7 14. Nf5 Ng8 15. Qd4
comment: A very powerfull continuation, which I didn't anticipate.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. g3 b6 4. Bg2 Bb7 5. Nc3 d6 6. d4 cxd4 7. Nxd4 a6 8. O-O Nd7 9. f4 Ngf6 10. Re1 Qc7 11. g4 h6 12. Nd5 exd5 13. exd5+ Be7 14. Nf5 Ng8 15. Qd4 Ndf6 16. g5 hxg5 17. fxg5 O-O-O
comment: Only by giving back material black is able to continue fighting.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. g3 b6 4. Bg2 Bb7 5. Nc3 d6 6. d4 cxd4 7. Nxd4 a6 8. O-O Nd7 9. f4 Ngf6 10. Re1 Qc7 11. g4 h6 12. Nd5 exd5 13. exd5+ Be7 14. Nf5 Ng8 15. Qd4 Ndf6 16. g5 hxg5 17. fxg5 O-O-O 18. Nxe7+ Nxe7 19. gxf6 gxf6 20. Qxf6
comment:
This leads to a forced draw in different ways but
white needs strong nerves to master the complications. Therefore 20.c4 appears
more practical. After 20. ...Rdg8 the position is quit unclear with winning
chances for both sides.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. g3 b6 4. Bg2 Bb7 5. Nc3 d6 6. d4 cxd4 7. Nxd4 a6 8. O-O Nd7 9. f4 Ngf6 10. Re1 Qc7 11. g4 h6 12. Nd5 exd5 13. exd5+ Be7 14. Nf5 Ng8 15. Qd4 Ndf6 16. g5 hxg5 17. fxg5 O-O-O 18. Nxe7+ Nxe7 19. gxf6 gxf6 20. Qxf6 Nxd5 21. Qf5+ Kb8 22. Bxd5 Qc5+ 23. Be3 Rdg8+ 24. Kf1 Qxd5 25. Qxd5 Bxd5 26. Bf4
